Award.AwardTitle: Understanding and Monitoring Nanoparticle Self-Assembly Processes with Online Transmission Electron Microscopic Data

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this award is to develop a statistical methodology for understanding the dynamic aspects of nanoparticle production processes by using online measurements of the processes, and to study quality technology for achieving high-quality production of nanoparticles based on understanding the processes. Due to its potential for large-scale production, the main interest is in nanoparticle self-assembly, which assembles nanoparticles via their dynamic interactions. The developed methodology characterizes and uses the dynamic interactions for quality monitoring of the self-assembly. An optimization problem is formulated for automatically tracking individual nanoparticles and their interactions from the noisy online measurements of their self-assembly processes, and a computationally efficient sub-optimal algorithm is developed to solve the problem. The tracked particle interactions are fit to the proposed statistical-physical model for estimating unknown process parameters in an underlying physics-based model. Several empirical models are also developed for filling the void in the physics-based model. The PI will develop a new process monitoring method, which uses the values of the estimated process parameters, to test whether a nanoparticle self-assembly process is in normal condition and to locate special causes of process anomalies if available. A silver nanoparticle self-assembly is used as a prototypical process to validate the developed methodology.

If successful, this work will advance online process characterization and monitoring for nanoparticle production processes, thereby leading to high quality production of nanoparticles. In addition, the developed statistical-physical model will lead to a fundamental understanding of dynamic nanoscale phenomena in nanoparticles, which will help to expand the current research into nanoparticle physics and chemistry. The results of this work will be disseminated via publications and presentations, and will be used to provide education opportunities for closing the workforce deficit with skilled nano-process engineers through new courses, student mentoring, and workshop programs for K-12 students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project is to study a statistical methodology for understanding a nanoparticle production process through direct imagery observations of the process, and to study quality technology for achieving high-quality production of nanoparticles based on understanding. Major research challenges are on how to analyze a large volume of microscopic imagery observations to identify and track important sub processes of a nanoparticle production process buried in the noisy observations, and on modeling the data to understand how the sub processes are related to the final process outcomes, i.e. nanoparticle products.  In this project, the PI investigated a visual analytics method to track the sub processes and nanoparticles, and studied a statistical modeling to statistically correlate the occurrences of the sub processes with the resulting morphology of nanoparticle products, based on the sub process information and nanoparticles tracked through direct process measurements. The modeling development became the basis to build a quality monitoring tool to monitor and detect process anomalies that causes abnormal morphology changes in nanoparticle products.

Major findings are summarized as follows. First, the existing tracking algorithms of automatically tracking events in a stream of imagery observations lack the capabilities of tracking important sub processes of a nanoparticle production process. In particular, a sub process involving interactions among multiple materials cannot be effectively tracked by the existing approaches, because the existing approaches can track materials individually but not interactions of them. The PI proposed a new optimization problem to track individual materials and their interactions, so important sub processes involving the interactions could be successfully captured with high accuracy.

Second, the existing process modeling and quality monitoring methods lacks some features necessary for monitoring and detecting process anomalies in a nanoparticle production process. The key quality characteristics of  nanoparticle production is the particle geometries resulting from the production, which are too complex to model by the existing approaches that can model quality features as simple numerical values. In addition, we observed that the key quality characteristics in nanoparticle production change in multiple different pathways, which cannot be monitored by the existing approaches that can only monitor single pathway of process changes. The PI studied a new quality monitoring model that can monitor multi-modal changes of geometrical features of products.

The methodological developments were applied to a silver nanoparticle production process, which showed that the new methods were capable of locating and detecting process anomalies with high accuracy and quick time to detection. The methods were broadly applied to understand other fundamental nanomaterial systems such as understanding the growth kinetics of nanoparticle self-assembly process, understanding the degradation mechanism of Li-ion battery and understanding a nanoparticle-based drug delivery system.

The PI also developed several education modules based on the result of this proposal activity, one for high school scholars participating in the FSU's Young Scholars Program, one for undergraduate students participating in the High Performance Material's Summer Research Program, and another for graduate teaching. We hosted two high school students every year during the project period and hosted two undergraduate students. In addition, new course contents were developed for the graduate data mining course and the undergraduate quality control course.

The results of the project were broadly disseminated in the form of journal paper publications and open source software. The PI wrote 22 peer-reviewed journal articles, including 10 for statistical methodology and 9 for application. The statistical methodology papers were published or submitted to top journals of applied statistics and industrial engineering, Technometrics, Journal of Quality Technology, Annals of Applied Statistics, IISE Transactions and Journal of Machine Learning Research. The application papers were published to top science journals of ACS Nano, Nano Letters and Journal of American Chemical Society. Resulting software and data were published as open source software via the internet portal of DOE National Labs and the PI’s website. 

 


Last Modified: 10/30/2017
Modified by: Chiwoo Park

Image
  • Summary of the Final Project Outcome: Direct microscope imagery observations of a nanoparticle production process was analyzed (A) to automatically track individual nanoparticle products and their interactions, (B) to capture important key process characteristics and (C) to monitor the process.
    Chiwoo Park (cpark5@fsu.edu)

    Chiwoo Park
    Summary of the Final Project Outcome
